results.title: One past eight futures "The making of"
results.brief_description: This mini-documentary takes us behind the scenes of the ‘One past eight futures’ Digital Storytelling workshop at ACMI. The participants of this particular workshop are eight young indigenous people who are part of the Indigenous Youth Leadership program. They discuss their stories, their participation in the workshop and what they have gained from the experience. The results are a social and cultural snapshot of Australia’s Indigenous youth, through their stories, their ties to the past and, mostly, their hopes for the future.

results.title: Change!
results.creator_credit: Tori Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Tori Towney came from an encouraging and supportive family. Growing up, she resisted the urge to join her friends drinking and instead listened to the stories of her father, of his harsh and poor upbringing. When her mum encouraged her to move to Sydney and take up a scholarship at St Catherine’s, she grabbed this opportunity with both hands. Tori candidly shares what it was like to be away from home with no support network and how she overcame that and adapted to her new and exciting environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tori Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My tree
results.creator_credit: Kamsani Bin Salleh, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Families are always moving forward and tend to rarely dwell on the past. However, its important for Kamsani Bin Salleh to find out about his family history, for a greater sense of who he is, if nothing else. As he trawls his family history, he discovers the vast array of cultures that have contributed to his existence.

results.title: Dreaming in motion picture
results.creator_credit: Ian RT Colless, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Through music and footage of dance, Ian Colless weaves a tale, of his upbringing as a Gundungurra man, his home in the Blue Mountains and the journey to becoming a dancer. Ian has found a way to combine the various cultures and identities within him through dance, making his body a symbol of reconciliation and giving his people a voice.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian RT Colless, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Through music and footage of dance, Ian Colless weaves a tale, of his upbringing as a Gundungurra man, his home in the Blue Mountains and the journey to becoming a dancer. results.title: Ngay Wandabaa (My Spirit)
results.creator_credit: Ian Brown, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Ian Brown’ dedicates this Digital Story to his family and friends. He illustrates his life through the contributions and sacrifices made by the people closest to him, the encouragement of his parents, support of his sisters and sense of fraternity that he found with his friends when at school on his scholarship.

results.title: What's important to me?
results.creator_credit: Hamish Eden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hamish Eden is only thirteen, he is uncle to three nephews and a niece. He comes from a large family of twelve but Hamish shares the benefits of having so many brothers and sisters. They have been great role models to Hamish and have taught him many different things, above all the importance of education.

results.title: My family and home town
results.creator_credit: Gerald Phineasa, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Gerald Phineasa loves his family and small community of Bamaga in far North Queensland. His large family have plenty of animals and are starting to race horses and he looks forward to returning from his school break in Brisbane to days of riding and fishing. His town is small but somehow has everything Gerald would want. A loving tribute and a snapshot of a small rural community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gerald Phineasa, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Both cultures
results.creator_credit: Angel Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Angela Towney’s passion in life is for martial arts, for which she has competed around Australia and, she hopes, internationally. However, she acknowledges and pays homage to the influences that gave her the strength to achieve, her family and community in Wiradjuri country. Despite her father’s earlier troubles, his reform instilled a sense of pride and inner strength which allowed Angel to move beyond the community that she loved to follow her passion. Despite the difficulty of traversing two cultures, the introspection of the East and the Indigenous sense of community, her firey ambition and her innate love of her community and land, Angel recognises that she is enriched and embraced by both.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Angel Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Angela Towney’s passion in life is for martial arts, for which she has competed around Australia and, she hopes, internationally. However, she acknowledges and pays homage to the influences that gave her the strength to achieve, her family and community in Wiradjuri country. Despite her father’s earlier troubles, his reform instilled a sense of pride and inner strength which allowed Angel to move beyond the community that she loved to follow her passion. Despite the difficulty of traversing two cultures, the introspection of the East and the Indigenous sense of community, her firey ambition and her innate love of her community and land, Angel recognises that she is enriched and embraced by both.

Despite her father’s earlier troubles, his reform instilled a sense of pride and inner strength which allowed Angel to move beyond the community that she loved to follow her passion. Despite the difficulty of traversing two cultures, the introspection of the East and the Indigenous sense of community, her firey ambition and her innate love of her community and land, Angel recognises that she is enriched and embraced by both.

results.title: DST July 09 presents...
results.brief_description: ACMI Digital Storytelling interviews the six participants of the Foundation of Young Australians workshop in July 2009. They are asked questions in regard to the process, what they learned and the experience of telling their stories. This is also intercut with footage from the actual workshop and serves as a behind the scenes documentary to capture the process of Digital Storytelling as well as the impact on the participants.

results.title: What makes me, me
results.creator_credit: Robbie Palm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: One of Robbie Palm’s favourite things is fishing at the creek of his nan’s property. Even though he goes to boarding school in Brisbane, he returns during school holidays to fish. He has been taught by his family the techniques and it is this, and when he plays the Didgeridoo that Robbie feels most connected to his culture. When he plays, he feels proud and watched by his family, both current and past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robbie Palm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
